title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of the total number of complaints received for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. Victims of identity theft may experience damaged credit records, unauthorized charges on credit cards, unauthorized withdrawals from bank accounts, and may need to change personal information like phone numbers, social security numbers, and addresses. Theft fraud accounted for 24% of complaints, leading to damaged credit records, unauthorized charges, and withdrawals. Victims may need to change personal information like phone numbers and addresses due to identity theft. Federal laws assist in purging inaccurate credit information and imposing penalties on identity thieves using fraudulent documents. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud related to identification documents, including consumer identity theft. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud in connection with identification documents, including consumer identity theft. Offenses under the statute include producing or possessing stolen identification documents, transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority, and aiding unlawful activities. Punishments for fraud related to identification documents vary. The federal law prohibits the transfer or use of another person's identification without lawful authority to commit unlawful activities. Punishments for fraud related to identification documents vary depending on the offense, with penalties including fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, and up to 25 years for offenses related to international terrorism. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act was signed in 2004. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed in 2004, defines penalties for aggravated identity theft, with a two-year imprisonment term in addition to the original felony punishment. Offenses related to drug trafficking or violence could lead to up to twenty years in prison, while those connected to international terrorism may result in up to twenty-five years of imprisonment. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed in 2004, imposes a two-year imprisonment term for identity theft in addition to the original felony punishment. Offenses related to terrorism may result in an additional five-year imprisonment. The act also directs the United States Sentencing Commission to adjust guidelines for punishing identity theft offenses. Additionally, it authorizes appropriations to the Justice Department for investigating and prosecuting identity theft cases. The Fair Credit Reporting Act may assist victims in removing negative information resulting from unauthorized charges or accounts from their credit files. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) aims to assist victims of identity theft by allowing them to have negative information removed from their credit files. It outlines consumer rights, permissible uses for credit reports, and imposes duties on consumer reporting agencies to ensure accuracy. Consumers can file suit for violations, such as inaccurate information disclosure. The FCRA imposes duties on consumer reporting agencies and information furnishers to ensure accuracy. Consumers can file suit for violations, including inaccurate information disclosure. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes amendments to prevent identity theft and assist victims. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes amendments to prevent identity theft and assist victims by creating national standards for addressing consumer concerns. New provisions require credit card issuers to follow procedures for address changes and truncation of account numbers on receipts. Consumers can request fraud alerts and have social security numbers truncated on credit reports. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes provisions to prevent identity theft and assist victims. Consumers can request fraud alerts and have information blocked from their credit reports. Fraud alerts can be maintained for 90 days or up to seven years with an extended alert. The alerts are passed along to all users of the credit report. Victims of identity theft can request a fraud alert and have fraudulent information blocked from their credit reports. Consumer reporting agencies must block the information upon receiving proof of identity theft, notify the furnisher of the information, and refer requests to other agencies. Victims can also request information about the crime and businesses must provide transaction records upon verification of identity. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and billing errors in credit transactions. It aims to protect consumers from inaccurate credit billing practices by providing a procedure for resolving disputes. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute billing errors, including unauthorized charges and charges for goods or services not received. Consumers can file a claim with the creditor to have errors resolved, and until then, they are not required to pay the disputed amount. The creditor must investigate and correct any confirmed billing errors, crediting the consumer's account. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act provides a mechanism for challenging unauthorized transactions and having accounts recredited. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) allows consumers to challenge unauthorized transactions and have their accounts recredited. It establishes rights, liabilities, and responsibilities for electronic fund transfers, limiting consumer liability for unauthorized transfers. Financial institutions must provide documentation of all electronic fund transfers initiated by the consumer. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) limits consumer liability for unauthorized transfers to $50 or the amount of the unauthorized transfers before notice. Financial institutions must provide documentation of all electronic fund transfers initiated by the consumer and investigate any errors reported by the consumer within 60 days. The consumer must provide the financial institution with their name, account number, belief of error, and reasons for the error. If an error is confirmed, the institution must correct it within one day. They can temporarily credit the consumer's account while investigating. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to combat identity theft. The Identity Theft Task Force's final recommendations in April 2007 aimed to crack down on criminals trafficking in stolen identities, protect personal information, assist law enforcement in prosecuting identity thieves, educate consumers and businesses on protection, and increase safeguards on personal data. The recommendations focus on improving data security, making it harder for identity thieves, aiding victims in recovery, and deterring theft through aggressive prosecution. Recommendations include amending statutes to ensure increased federal prosecution for identity theft-related offenses. The Identity Theft Task Force's recommendations in April 2007 aimed to crack down on criminals trafficking in stolen identities and protect personal information. The Task Force recommended amending federal criminal statutes to prosecute identity theft-related offenses more effectively. Key recommendations include amending identity theft and aggravated identity theft statutes, adding new crimes to the list of predicate offenses, penalizing creators of malicious spyware, and enhancing sentences for identity thieves affecting multiple victims. Additionally, the Department of Homeland Security published a final rule in 2008 for State-issued driver's licenses and identification cards accepted for official purposes. The Real ID Act of 2005 established standards for State-issued driver's licenses and identification cards accepted for official purposes. States can receive extensions until December 31, 2009, and those meeting security benchmarks can extend until May 10, 2011. The Rule includes requirements for information and security features, proof of identity, verification of source documents, and security standards for issuing offices. The Real ID Act of 2005 sets security standards for state-issued licenses and IDs. States can get extensions until December 31, 2009, and some can extend until May 10, 2011 if they meet security benchmarks. The rule requires states to replace non-compliant licenses with REAL ID cards by specific dates based on birth year. Effective March 31, 2008.
